(7P) A political game where players try to get as much money out of a failed nation state without getting killed by your rivals. Players will attempt to stay in power, by enlisting the other players and paying them enough to keep them loyal. This loyalty is tested during coups, which in terms of gameplay slows the game down and gives it a more serious atmosphere. The game fails to properly consolidate the two modes of play that this game offers.
Fun but broken.

This game had so much potential if they had made a propper battle system for the reprint. Anything will do better then the current battle system. As a Role Playing Game, it is outstanding and very funny.

For me, the description on the back of the box was the best part of the game. I was so excited to give this one a go, but that ended shortly after starting the game. Games are supposed to be fun, and this one should have been right up my ally, but it fell overwhelmingly short.

Shows its age. Really overwrought game time for the experience it offers, it is not worth the time investment at all. The card play is a crapshoot - so few meaningful choices to be made. The most interesting part of the game is choosing which location to go to and, if you have the ability to assassinate, who to target and trying to guess where they are. The whole combat portion of the game is a bore and could be resolved in a fraction of the time. This game is a relic that I have no nostalgia for.

I also found that the last round seems like a waste, as the coup does nothing, and being el presidente at the end of the game doesn't do anything.

Game was interesting, to say the least. It was relatively fast-paced and has very many twist and turns, with betrayal and deal at every point. The game did feel a bit all over the place, though. My group played for about three hours and we never really fully understood the game and made mistakes the whole time. Also, the end of the game was very disappointing. We finished off with a final coup attempt, but because of the way the resolution phase works, we had one or two people deciding who wins the game, which is never a fun way to end. I couldn't imagine playing for longer and we ended up take away half of the money deck so the game would go faster. The multi-staged gameplay kept me attentive the whole time, but the game can be very unbalanced if one person gets better cards/more votes in the voting phase. Probably better to play with an even amount of players, so that it can end up usually being a 2v2 or a 3v3.

A game that is only enjoyable thanks to the people that you play with.

As a pure piece of game design it clearly shows its age. For one, the game length is terrible. It is so misshapen. I actually really enjoy the concept of a light-hearted negotiation game carrying quite an elaborate wargame within it. However, that individual wargame 'coup' section can sometimes take 45minutes+ if the battle runs close.

And then you are simply back to the negotiation module with barely any significant long lasting changes. Rinse and repeat. There is also something strange about how performing a 45 minute coup has the same gameplay impact as succeeding with a 1 minute-to-resolve assassination attempt. It is all so uneven. If this was made today, i am sure that there are numerous ways to make this a more coherent and polished experience whist not losing any of the core experience or appeal.

And there is some appeal here. Assigning a budget and cabinet is fun. The game wears its heart on its sleeve and kind of knows what it is. How much actual control you have over proceedings is worrying though; an epic 5 hour game can come down to one correct guess or swing of luck from a single dice. In that regard, the game is simply old, beaten bananas....

Familias tratan de hacerse millonarias en una república bananera. Politiqueo, revolución, asesinados y complots. Admite muchos jugadores aunque es un juego de larga duración.

Junta is a fun and, at times, quite silly game of constant backstabbing. You can raise a coup d'etat and contract killers with one single objective: take possession of your opponents' money. So yes, it's a game of being mean, but in a fun way.

In junta players form the government of a banana republic. The objective isn't to actually rule the country, but to steal as much money from it as you can. A key mechanism is, whenever you die, you loose all the money you have in your hands. In order for it to be accounted, you need to make it to the bank, to deposit it in your Swiss bank account.

Each turn, the president proposes how to distribute the foreign aid, on which the rest of the players vote. But what if you disagree? What if the voting passed and you didn't liked its outcome? Coup! Another player received more money than you? Coup! But what if you don't feel like starting a coup? Coup! I mean, assassin! It's a game of negotiation and backstabbing, yes, but the atmosphere is so chaotic that you don't feel much like being betrayed: it's simply the natural course.

A coup d'etat starts a mini war game in which players take sides for either the president or the rebels. Don't think about it much though: you can change sides at almost any time. Players are given a certain amount of troops, depending on their office, and must take control of certain strategical locations. The side who controls the most locations wins, moment in which its respective leader chooses someone to be shot. Then the leader may share the loot if he feels keeping all the money would be greedy he won't make it to the bank without creating a couple of extra targets.

The game's main flaw is its downtime. The game doesn't reward careful planning, it rewards constant backstabbing. Think too much and other players will think you are up to something, thus other players will want to kill you. Thinking is counter productive. The key is making temporary alliances, not planning a master move.

The game is, at heart, chaotic. If a player fails to accept and embrace its nature, it can ruin its pace. This can be particularly troublesome during coups, where combat is really random and, in the end, it depends on whom sides with whom. Troop positioning is not all that important important: whom wants to backstab whom is.

Basically, this is Junta. The rules are a bit clunky to explain, but very thematic, so you just need to see how a round in action to understand its flow of play. The game's core is so mean spirited the atmosphere is much more relaxed than in other betrayal-prone games. When everyone is constantly at each other's throats, when alliances last mere minutes, betrayals stop feeling personal and become stupidly hilarious.

Junta (2015) AEG, English edition
2-7 players, best 6-7

Fun game of Banana Republic politics, if you can find the right 6-7 cutthroat gamers to play with you! And that's its main problem, finding enough of the right players. The second problem is its length at 4+ hours. But other than that, it's a unique game. I urge you to read more about it on its BGG page.

Big pro: All players remain in contention to the very end, for no one knows who has managed to smuggle (and retain) the most money into their Swiss bank account!

This 2015 edition has:
Bigger map, some component changes, and a few rule changes (for example, Exile and Combat) have been made to improve the game play.

Do we now have the Ultimate Edition? Hm. Some things may be better than the 1985 German Edition, and some less. I prefer a more readable map, the original family symbols, and the Cold War era setting. However, it's a good quality version of the game and should not deter anyone from purchase.

Junta is one of those rare games that shine best with the full complement of 7 players!

Note:
Junta: Viva el Presidente! is supposedly a lite version of the original Junta. Appears to be very much changed, not near the same game. The goal/victory condition is quite different (no more embezzling money to your swiss account). There is no city map, which had been used during a putsch attempt. Are there even influence cards in it? Have not played it to be able to give a rating, but I am very doubtful that it can capture the original´s experience.



vtsaogames wrote:
gavken wrote:
I like Junta but I don't love it. In my view the whole coup part takes way too long and distracts from the rest of the game. You can end up playing very long games of Junta because you have coups nearly every round.
Suggestion: if you find the coup phase too long, have the first rebel roll a die, then the president. Then have each player clockwise around the table declare what side they are on and roll a die. Keep track of each side's total. Once all have declared, if the rebel total is higher, they overthrow the government. Otherwise el Presidente remains in power. You can say the original designer suggested this. But do get the other players to agree before staring the game. From time to time I have seen folks online who talk about playing the coup phase with miniature soldiers and tanks.

If you don't like the clockwise method, have all uncommitted players roll a die. The highest roll must commit and roll again. Settle ties by a dice-off between tied players.

I do think this will speed up the game at a slight cost in flavor.

What a fantastic game! My Junta career started out with a really old version which had a cloth map for resolving coups. Sadly that one's gone, but I got a copy of the West End English edition, and suddenly it was back to the Banana Republic!

For me, this game has everything, diplomacy, skulduggery, out-and-out treachery... and of course, lots and lots of money to be diverted to your Swiss Bank Account. When the time comes, and you feel those in government are not "showing you the respect" (ie giving you enough loot) you deserve, you can launch a coup with your faction and other powerful families against the tyrants, to become either a great and grand hero of the revolution, or a martyr for the cause!

Enormously fun game to share with non-gamers with the proper sense of humor, particularly if those non-gamers are a bit erratic.

This really needs at least 6 players to work properly, but if you get them, and have a beer and put on some thick skin, you can't have more fun gaming in an evening.

This, to me, is how you make a diplomacy style game. This game tricks you into thinking its a political war game, but that is simply not the case. The economic card hoarding alliance forming friendship mourning that is junta should be tried by many. Only complaint is the same gameplay is played over and over with little change, making longer games drag a tad. High recommendation from me

Un vrai jeu d'enfoirés

De la négociation à chaque instant pour tirer la couverture à soi, et se faire des amis, le temps de mettre quelques billets sur son compte suisse sans se faire exécuter, voler, ou destituer.
Il faut lire le jeu, les joueurs, sentir le vent tourner ou alors provoquer ce retournement, affaiblir les alliés de ses ennemis ou les corrompre. Ça peut devenir très chaotique, ça dépend beaucoup des mentalités autour de la table, ce sont réellement les joueurs qui font le jeu. Mais qu'est-ce que c'est fun au final.

Le jeu est un peu long les premières parties, le temps de le prendre en main mais si on a des bons enfoirés à table, qui ne perdent pas l'objectif de vue, on ne voit pas le temps passer

What I love about it:
* communication is so important
* politics is so important
* nobody is safe, everybody mistrusts everybody
* once you understand the flow of the game and that there are almost no other rules than the flow itself, it is a very easy to play experience.
